Award.AwardTitle: Doane DIVAS: Digital Imaging and Vision Applications in Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Digital Imaging and Vision Applications in Science (DIVAS) project will have strong significance and importance toward advancing the prosperity and welfare of the country by creating a pedagogical and programmatic 'onramp' of computational materials that empower natural science majors to engage in authentic computational problems. DIVAS will ultimately increase the number of skilled computationally trained scientists entering the workforce, addressing the critical shortage of these workers.

DIVAS' goal is to develop, use, and test instructional practices and curricular innovations that will engage and train STEM undergraduates in computation and computing related to image processing. The scope will be to assess practices and innovations in the traditional classroom environment, in informal training 'boot camps', and in undergraduate research settings for their impact on student self-efficacy, computational competency, and intended and actual career paths. The project team will use an established instrument for assessing self-efficacy in computation and will develop a new tool to assess computational competency across a wide range of educational settings. Growth in self-efficacy, computational skills, and career choice will be assessed each time a student engages in a DIVAS innovation. This collaborative project will establish and strengthen partnerships with key academic institutions and organizations and will prioritize practices and innovations for adoption within a broader DIVAS network. DIVAS will test the effectiveness of educational interventions occurring in the traditional learning environment, in informal training environments, and in professional settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Doane University, a small, private comprehensive liberal arts institution with a residential undergraduate campus in rural Nebraska, was awarded an NSF IUSE grant to assess a series of interventions aimed at improving the computational self-efficacy and computational skills of undergraduates majoring in biological and chemical sciences. Doane partnered with faculty at St. Edward?s University, a private minority-serving institution in Austin, Texas, to implement the project. The natural sciences are experiencing a data generation explosion that now requires scientists in these fields to be competent in using computational tools to analyze data and effectively communicate with computer science experts to solve more challenging computational problems. 

The mathematical and computational training of natural science majors is still minimal in most undergraduate-level programs. Furthermore, it is still relatively common for students majoring in these fields to not see themselves as skilled in math or computing. To meet the increasing need for computational competency within biology and chemistry disciplines while also addressing the reality that underlying self-efficacy is typically low, we designed the DIVAS (Digital Imaging and Vision Applications in Science) Program.

The DIVAS program consists of a year-long series of scaffolded experiences that center on using images as data. Images are easily accessible and provide interesting problems from a wide array of fields students generally find interesting. The DIVAS program begins with a one-credit seminar in the spring that introduces students to images, coding, and professions that use both. This seminar is followed by a one-week intensive coding workshop and four weeks of working on two common coding problems in pairs and whole-group code reviews. Scholars had the option to pursue independent research over the summer and finished the program with a capstone seminar the following spring. As part of the capstone seminar, scholars curated the code developed the previous summer and learned about advanced computing techniques. 

Using images as our ?hook? and requiring only interest and no previous computing experience, we recruited students enrolled in introductory biology and chemistry courses. DIVAS Scholars received stipends for their participation in the program. Over the three-year grant, a total of seventeen scholars participated, five or six each year. One scholar each year was selected from St. Edward?s University and worked mostly remotely with the scholars at Doane University. One scholar majoring in computer science was also selected each year to promote interdisciplinary collaboration. Seventy-six percent of our participants were women, and fourteen percent came from underrepresented minority groups.

The program elements were structured within the context of a Community of Practice where all members (faculty, scholars, other participants, and facilitators) engaged with each other as colleagues there to learn from and teach each other. The faculty modeled this organizational style by fluidly shifting between teacher, facilitator, and learner roles. In retrospect, this inclusive, supportive environment may have been a major contributor to the very high retention we observed (100% of scholars were still majoring in STEM fields one year after finishing the program) and likely contributed to the positive impact on the self-efficacy of participants toward computing.

Overall, we saw steady, significant gains in scholar self-efficacy toward computing, even while the computing tasks themselves became more complex and challenging. We observed an average increase in self-efficacy of 32%. To measure growth in computational skill, the team designed a computational thinking rubric to score participant responses to coding logic tasks and the code generated in the program. We saw significant gains in computational thinking skill after the coding workshop and group coding projects using this new tool. At least half of the scholars elected to extend their experience with the program by continuing with research. Furthermore, approximately half of the scholars elected to take their experience further by taking additional coursework or applying for jobs, experiences, and graduate programs that would require the use of and further development of their computational skills. Our coding workshop?s image processing portion was also adopted as a workshop for international distribution through the Data Carpentry Foundation. This workshop has already been offered to various groups (mostly at the graduate level and beyond) in both the United States and Germany.

In summary, this pilot program testing the effectiveness of implementing coding experiences using images as data in a Community of Practice context was promising in its effect on participant self-efficacy toward computing, retention in STEM, and interest in gaining additional computation experience. Our goal is to expand this program?s implementation with a larger pool of scholars in both face-to-face and remote settings to confirm these initial results and inform how to effectively implement the program on a large scale.
